content: The "State and Local Aid and Economic Stimulus Act of 2003" provides a one-time revenue grant to states and local governments. The "State and Local Aid and Economic Stimulus Act of 2003" authorizes a $40 billion one-time revenue grant to States and local governments. The grant is to be appropriated for fiscal year 2003, with $20 billion allotted based on population. The "State and Local Aid and Economic Stimulus Act of 2003" authorizes a $40 billion one-time revenue grant to States and local governments. $10 billion is allotted based on population at the local government level, and $20 billion is based on the change in unemployment rate at the state level. The "State and Local Aid and Economic Stimulus Act of 2003" authorizes a $40 billion one-time revenue grant to States and local governments. $10 billion is allotted based on population at the local government level, and $20 billion is based on the change in unemployment rate at the state level. Additionally, $2,500,000,000 shall be allotted among States with tier 1 unemployment rates for distribution to local government units based on the number of unemployed individuals in each unit. The Secretary will allot $7,500,000,000 among States with tier 2 unemployment rates based on the number of unemployed individuals in each State for distribution to local government units. The Secretary will distribute funds to local government units based on the number of unemployed individuals in each State for calendar year 2002. Congress prioritizes funding for homeland security, medicaid, public health, highway construction, childcare, education, and preventing property tax increases. The term 'unit of general local government' includes counties, cities, and tribal governing bodies with substantial governmental duties and powers in the United States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The rules under section 6720(c) of title 31, United States Code, apply for determining a unit of general local government. Unemployment rates are categorized as tier 1 and tier 2 based on specific criteria for calendar year 2002. In calendar year 2002, the unemployment rate was more than 1.0 percentage point higher than in 2000. A conforming amendment was made to the table of sections for chapter 67 of title 31, United States Code. One-time revenue grant to States and local governments.
